Idiom (Madurese): Mon tak e patet, batu bisa tak onggu’
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: With persistence, even the hardest task can be done.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Nothing is impossible if you try hard enough.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from Madurese farming wisdom symbolizing patience and effort.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Madurese): /mon tak e patet, batu bisa tak oŋguʔ/
First Example Sentence: Ebu’ sering ngomong, ‘Mon tak e patet, batu bisa tak onggu’, ben saengko’ jhe’ gampang nyerah.
Second Example Sentence: Guru ngajhi ngoca’ idiom itu pas ngajhar sabar.
Third Example Sentence: Oreng tani biasana ngoca’ begitoh pas kerja berat e ladang.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone who doesn’t belong or acts out of place.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional expression referencing physical displacement to convey social mismatch.
First Example Sentence: Areh, ajunan jhe’ cocok ben kelompok eah, ka’ ajuna jhe’ ka’ apote.
Second Example Sentence: Guru ketawa pas anak salah duduk, ‘ka’ ajuna jhe’ ka’ apote!’
Third Example Sentence: Mon oreng jhe’ ngerti aturan, sering e bilang begitoh.

Idiom (Madurese): Lemmah jhe’ ta’ etandur oreng jhe’ panen
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone benefits from others’ hard work.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: He/she took credit for someone else’s effort.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in agrarian imagery reflecting fairness and labor ethics.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Madurese): /lemah ʤheʔ taʔ etandur oreŋ ʤheʔ panen/
First Example Sentence: Proyek e sukses, tapeh bosna se dapet pujian, lemah jhe’ ta’ etandur oreng jhe’ panen.
Second Example Sentence: Ajunan kerja keras, tapeh se laen se e puji.
Third Example Sentence: Ungkapan ini sering e pakeh pas oreng curhat soal keadilan.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone who can’t stay still or restless.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional domestic metaphor comparing restlessness to uneven pillows.
First Example Sentence: Ana’ itu bhun jhe’ bantal, sakedhik-sakedhik ngadeg.
Second Example Sentence: Pas ngaji, se oreng tak bisa diam, e bilang bhun jhe’ bantal.
Third Example Sentence: Istri e bilang suamena bhun jhe’ bantal pas libur.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Looking for something impossible or unrealistic.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: That’s an impossible thing to do.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Symbolic of futility in traditional Madurese sayings.
First Example Sentence: Ajunan nyare’ kerja tanpa usaha, sama ben nyare’ bintang e siang hari.
Second Example Sentence: Guru ngomong begituh pas siswa males belajar.
Third Example Sentence: Idiomeh sering muncul e puisi Madura klasik.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A person who speaks bluntly or without thinking.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: He/she speaks without considering others’ feelings.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to local food imagery; ‘lemur’ symbolizes rawness and lack of refinement.
First Example Sentence: Ajunan jhe’ bisa ngoca’ sembarangan, tak ka’ lemur e tengka.
Second Example Sentence: Oreng se ceplas-ceplos sering e sebut lemur e tengka.
Third Example Sentence: Guru ngingetna siswa ben tak ka’ lemur e tengka.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone with a kind or pure heart.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in Madurese moral expression symbolizing purity and compassion.
First Example Sentence: Ebu’ se tolang ateh, atena se tolang.
Second Example Sentence: Oreng e kampong bilang, ajunan jhe’ atena se tolang.
Third Example Sentence: Idiomeh sering e gunakna pas pujian.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Doing something doomed to fail or self-defeating.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional saying based on daily experience of wind extinguishing torches.
First Example Sentence: Ajunan marah ke oreng keras kepala, nyapo’ obor e angin.
Second Example Sentence: Guru bilang begituh pas siswanna tak mau denger.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone out of their depth or overwhelmed.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: He/she is in a situation beyond their ability.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: From coastal Madurese communities where frogs cannot survive in the sea.
First Example Sentence: Oreng anyar e kantor tak ngerti aturan, ibarat kaco’ e laok.
Second Example Sentence: Ajunan tak cocok e posisi itu, kaco’ e laok.
Third Example Sentence: Idiomeh sering e pakeh pas ejekan halus.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Wasting money on nothing or being scammed.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to market fraud common in old Madurese trade.
First Example Sentence: Ajunan beli barang online palsu, ibarat beli angin ben duit.
Second Example Sentence: Oreng pasar ngomong begituh pas kena tipu.
Third Example Sentence: Idiomeh sering e gunakna pas cerita lucu ekonomi.
